title: 110_s2960
content: The Act is titled the "National Improvised Explosive Device Prevention and Preparedness Act of 2008". It includes findings related to improvised explosive devices. The "National Improvised Explosive Device Prevention and Preparedness Act of 2008" acknowledges the threat posed by various forms of improvised explosive devices, including radio-controlled, suicide, vehicle-borne, waterborne, and underwater devices. The United States has experienced numerous attacks involving improvised explosive devices over the past 25 years, such as the 1983 bombings in Beirut and the Senate bombing. The 1983 United States Senate bombing, 1984 United States embassy annex bombing in Beirut, 1986 TWA Flight 840 bombing, 1986 LaBelle Discotheque bombing in Berlin, 1988 Pan Am Flight 103 bombing, 1993 World Trade Center bombing in New York City, 1995 Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building bombing in Oklahoma City, 1996 Khobar Towers bombing in Saudi Arabia, 1996 Centennial Olympic Park bombing in Atlanta, 1998 health clinic bombing in Birmingham. The 1998 health clinic bombing in Birmingham, Alabama; the 1998 United States embassy bombings in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania and Nairobi, Kenya; the 2000 USS Cole bombing in Aden, Yemen; and the 2008 military recruiting office bombing in New York City. Improvised explosive devices cause a majority of US combat casualties in Iraq and Afghanistan. Knowledge to make and detonate these devices is easily spread due to global communication networks. The United States lacks adequate capabilities and federal funding for responding to domestic improvised explosive device attacks. State and local bomb squads, dive teams, canine units, and SWAT teams are often the first to respond but face funding shortfalls. Funding shortfalls are identified based on threats from Federal, State, and local government sources. SEC. 3. BOMBING PREVENTION. Amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to include an Office for Bombing Prevention. The term 'IED first responder' refers to specific teams operated by State or local governments. An Office for Bombing Prevention is established within the Agency to enhance the Nation's ability to prevent terrorist improvised explosive device attacks. Responsibilities include coordinating national prevention activities, leading task forces, and assessing requirements and capabilities. The Office for Bombing Prevention coordinates national prevention activities and assesses requirements and capabilities of IED first responders at Federal, State, and local levels to deter, prevent, detect, and respond to terrorist explosive attacks. The Office for Bombing Prevention coordinates national prevention activities, assesses requirements and capabilities of IED first responders, and serves as the primary conduit between Federal, State, and local governments for conducting assessments and making necessary changes to close identified gaps. Additionally, it assists State and local officials in developing multijurisdictional bombing prevention plans. The Office for Bombing Prevention coordinates national prevention activities, assesses IED first responders' equipment requirements, maintains an information portal for sharing critical information, promotes awareness programs, liaises with the Joint Improvised Explosive Device Defeat Organization, and assists in developing multijurisdictional bombing prevention plans. The Office for Bombing Prevention coordinates national prevention activities, assesses equipment requirements, maintains an information portal, promotes awareness programs, liaises with organizations, and assists in developing bombing prevention plans. Federal, State, or local government agencies work on national explosive detection canine training and certification standards. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years. Functions of the Office for Bombing Prevention of the Department of Homeland Security are transferred to the Office for Bombing Prevention established under the Homeland Security Act. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a Senior Advisory Committee on Improvised Explosive Device Prevention and Response. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to establish the Senior Advisory Committee on Improvised Explosive Device Prevention and Response, responsible for providing policy guidance, recommendations, and best practices for emergency response providers in dealing with destructive devices. The Senior Advisory Committee on Bombing Prevention and Response is responsible for promoting interoperability and information sharing among IED first responders, reviewing grant applications, and providing advice on grant allocation. Members are selected in consultation with the Attorney General, Commandant of the Coast Guard, and Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration. The Senior Advisory Committee on Bombing Prevention and Response includes key members such as the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration, the Executive Director of the National Tactical Officers Association, the President of the National Sheriff's Association, and others. The Senior Advisory Committee on Bombing Prevention and Response includes key members such as the President of the United States Conference of Mayors, Regional Administrators of FEMA, and the head of the Office for Bombing Prevention. SEC. 5. IMPROVISED EXPLOSIVE DEVICE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE GRANTS. Title V of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a FIRST RESPONDER IED PREVENTION AND RESPONSE GRANT PROGRAM. Establishment of the First Responder IED Prevention and Response Grant Program allows the Administrator to provide grants to State and local governments. Applications for grants must be submitted according to the Administrator's requirements. Grant funds can be used for equipment, training, and salary/benefits for IED first responders, including veterans. The First Responder IED Prevention and Response Grant Program provides grants to State and local governments for equipment, training, and salary/benefits for IED first responders. Eligibility criteria include being a veteran with experience in Iraq or Afghanistan, a graduate of a military education school for explosive ordnance disposal technicians or explosive detection canine handlers, or a certified bomb technician law enforcement officer. The Administrator shall award grants under the First Responder IED Prevention and Response Grant Program based on identified gaps through a database. Authorization of appropriations includes $75,000,000 for fiscal year 2009, $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, $125,000,000 for fiscal year 2012, and $125,000,000 for fiscal year 2013. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The table of contents in the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include new sections related to Office for Bombing Prevention, First Responder IED Prevention and Response Grant Program, and Senior Advisory Committee on Improvised Explosive Device Prevention and Response. SEC. 7. MARITIME TRANSPORTATION SECURITY. Section 70107(k)(3) of title 46, United States Code is amended to identify necessary funding modifications for addressing vulnerabilities and capability gaps identified by the Coast Guard and the dive team component of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 database. This includes ensuring compliance with Area Maritime Transportation Security Plans and facility security plans, as well as assessing progress in completing assessments for the dive team component. The dive team component of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 database is being assessed for all applicable ports.
